intro: Pilocarpus pennatifolius var. selloanus, commonly known as the Sello's prickly ash, is a species native to the Andean regions of South America. It is a small evergreen shrub characterized by its pinnately compound leaves and clusters of yellow flowers. The plant produces small, red berries that are an important food source for local wildlife. It thrives in dry, rocky soils and is often found in high-altitude environments. Due to its unique morphology and ecological role, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists.
